pull.title: qa: Cache only chain and wallet for regtest datadir
pull.body: mempool.dat should be empty and I don't see a need to copy it around when restoring from the cache.

events.body: utACK, though the opposite approach, listing the files and directories to be cached instead of the ones not to be cached, might lead to less surprises in the future.

rename.from: qa: Remove mempool.dat from cached regtest datadir
rename.to: qa: Cache only chain and wallet for regtest datadir

events.body: Thanks, yes, I like this much better. re-utACK

Nit, since you are importing `get_datadir_path`, add a commit replacing
```py
os.path.join(self.options.cachedir, "node" + str(i))
```
with
```py
get_datadir_path(self.options.cachedir, i)
```

events.message: qa: Cache only chain and wallet for regtest datadir

events.body:
Tested ACK fa2310572f4cfcd3322409ce7e37dde155fc4bc9

Think travis just needs a bump.

I've bumped travis twice, but it still fails.

Edit: 
```
/home/travis/.travis/job_stages: line 57: depends/arm-linux-gnueabihf/native/bin/ccache: No such file or directory
```
I'll try nuking the cache (for this PR).
```bash
$ travis cache -d -b PR.12638
```
Still no luck, I think you need to re-push.

You can safely ignore the failing signal from Travis, it is a bug on their
end. I am not going to invalidate review for that

On Mar 14, 2018 13:45, "Wladimir J. van der Laan" <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> Still no luck, I think you need to re-push.
>
> 
> You are receiving this because you authored the thread.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/12638#issuecomment-373007651>,
> or mute the thread
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AGGmv-J9M3NmsrlhDwbhtZwCidWfiwY8ks5teRDPgaJpZM4Sg9zp>
> .
>

> You can safely ignore the failing signal from Travis, it is a bug on their end. I am not going to invalidate review for that

I find that difficult, without travis passing on a PR you can't guarantee that it won't break the build.
But anyhow, if you're so sure, we'll just merge...

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -431,10 +431,11 @@ def _initialize_chain(self):
             self.nodes = []
             self.disable_mocktime()
             for i in range(MAX_NODES):
-                os.remove(log_filename(self.options.cachedir, i, "debug.log"))
-                os.remove(log_filename(self.options.cachedir, i, "wallets/db.log"))
-                os.remove(log_filename(self.options.cachedir, i, "peers.dat"))
-                os.remove(log_filename(self.options.cachedir, i, "fee_estimates.dat"))
+                os.remove(os.path.join(get_datadir_path(self.options.cachedir, i), "regtest", "debug.log"))
+                os.remove(os.path.join(get_datadir_path(self.options.cachedir, i), "regtest", "mempool.dat"))
+                os.remove(os.path.join(get_datadir_path(self.options.cachedir, i), "regtest", "wallets/db.log"))
+                os.remove(os.path.join(get_datadir_path(self.options.cachedir, i), "regtest", "peers.dat"))
+                os.remove(os.path.join(get_datadir_path(self.options.cachedir, i), "regtest", "fee_estimates.dat"))
comments.body:
Would be nice to avoid so much duplication, e.g. 
```python
def rm_cache_path(filename):
    os.remove(os.path.join(get_datadir_path(self.options.cachedir, i), "regtest", filename))
```
but this is fine as-is.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -430,11 +430,12 @@ def _initialize_chain(self):
             self.stop_nodes()
             self.nodes = []
             self.disable_mocktime()
+            def cache_path(*paths):
+                return os.path.join(get_datadir_path(self.options.cachedir, i), "regtest", *paths)
comments.body: `i` won't be in scope yet; have to declare this in the loop.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -430,11 +430,12 @@ def _initialize_chain(self):
             self.stop_nodes()
             self.nodes = []
             self.disable_mocktime()
+            def cache_path(*paths):
+                return os.path.join(get_datadir_path(self.options.cachedir, i), "regtest", *paths)
comments.body: I don't think that's necessary. Python will add the symbol i to the scope of the function, not the for  block. Though it might be clearer to just pass `i` in as a parameter.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -430,11 +430,12 @@ def _initialize_chain(self):
             self.stop_nodes()
             self.nodes = []
             self.disable_mocktime()
+            def cache_path(*paths):
+                return os.path.join(get_datadir_path(self.options.cachedir, i), "regtest", *paths)
comments.body: Oh, @laanwj is right. Still probably best to either parameterize or move this definition as-is under the `for` for clarity.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -430,11 +430,12 @@ def _initialize_chain(self):
             self.stop_nodes()
             self.nodes = []
             self.disable_mocktime()
+            def cache_path(*paths):
+                return os.path.join(get_datadir_path(self.options.cachedir, i), "regtest", *paths)
comments.body: Not that the performance overhead is relevant in this case, but I think defining a function inside a loop is generally frowned upon. AFAIK essentially it's instantiating an object every time.
